actypes.h

00020 
00021 #ifndef _AC_TYPES_H_
00022 #define _AC_TYPES_H_
00023 
00024 #ifdef __cplusplus
00025 extern "C" {
00026 #endif
00027 
00028 /* AC_ALPHABET_t:
00029  * defines the alphabet type.
00030  * Actually defining AC_ALPHABET_t as a char work as well, but sometimes we deal
00031  * with streams of other basic types e.g. integers or enumerators.
00032  * Although they consists of string of bytes (chars), but using their specific
00033  * types as AC_ALPHABET_t will lead to a better performance. so instead of
00034  * working with strings of chars, we assume that we are working with strings of
00035  * AC_ALPHABET_t and leave it optional for other users to define their
00036  * own alphabets.
00037 **/
00038 typedef char AC_ALPHABET_t;
00039 
00040 /* AC_REP_t:
00041  * Provides a more readable representative for a pattern.
00042  * because patterns themselves are not always suitable for displaying
00043  * (e.g. hex patterns), we offer this type to improve intelligibility
00044  * of output. Sometimes it can be also useful, when you are
00045  * retrieving patterns from a database, to maintain their identifiers in the
00046  * automata for further reference. we provisioned two possible types as a
00047  * union. you can add your desired type in it.
00048 **/
00049 typedef union AC_REP
00050 {
00051     const char * stringy; /* null-terminated string */
00052     unsigned long number;
00053 } AC_REP_t;
00054 
00055 /* AC_PATTERN_t:
00056  * This is the pattern type that must be fed into AC automata.
00057  * the 'astring' field is not null-terminated, because it can contain zero
00058  * value bytes. the 'length' field determines the number of AC_ALPHABET_t it
00059  * carries. the 'rep' field is described in AC_REP_t. despite
00060  * 'astring', 'rep' can have duplicate values for different given
00061  * AC_PATTERN_t. it is an optional field and you can just fill it with 0.
00062  * CAUTION:
00063  * Not always the 'astring' points to the correct position in memory.
00064  * it is the responsibility of your program to maintain a permanent allocation
00065  * for astring field.
00066 **/
00067 typedef struct AC_PATTERN
00068 {
00069     const AC_ALPHABET_t * astring; /* String of alphabets */
00070     unsigned int length; /* Length of pattern */
00071     AC_REP_t rep; /* Representative string (optional) */
00072 } AC_PATTERN_t;
00073 
00074 /* AC_TEXT_t:
00075  * The input text type that is fed to ac_automata_search() to be searched.
00076  * it is similar to AC_PATTERN_t. actually we could use AC_PATTERN_t as input
00077  * text, but for the purpose of being more readable, we defined this new type.
00078 **/
00079 typedef struct AC_TEXT
00080 {
00081     const AC_ALPHABET_t * astring; /* String of alphabets */
00082     unsigned int length; /* Length of string */
00083 } AC_TEXT_t;
00084 
00085 /* AC_MATCH_t:
00086  * Provides the structure for reporting a match in the text.
00087  * a match occurs when the automata reaches a final node. any final
00088  * node can match one or more pattern at a position in a text. the
00089  * 'patterns' field holds these matched patterns. obviously these
00090  * matched patterns have same end-position in the text. there is a relationship
00091  * between matched patterns: the shorter one is a factor (tail) of the longer
00092  * one. the 'position' maintains the end position of matched patterns. the
00093  * start position of patterns could be found by knowing their 'length' in
00094  * AC_PATTERN_t. e.g. suppose "recent" and "cent" are matched at
00095  * position 40 in the text, then the start position of them are 34 and 36
00096  * respectively. finally the field 'match_num' maintains the number of
00097  * matched patterns.
00098 **/
00099 typedef struct AC_MATCH
00100 {
00101     AC_PATTERN_t * patterns; /* Array of matched pattern */
00102     long position; /* The end position of matching pattern(s) in the text */
00103     unsigned int match_num; /* Number of matched patterns */
00104 } AC_MATCH_t;
00105 
00106 /* AC_STATUS_t:
00107  * Return status of an AC function
00108 **/
00109 typedef enum AC_STATUS
00110 {
00111     ACERR_SUCCESS = 0,          /* No error occurred */
00112     ACERR_DUPLICATE_PATTERN,    /* Duplicate patterns */
00113     ACERR_LONG_PATTERN,         /* Pattern length is longer than AC_PATTRN_MAX_LENGTH */
00114     ACERR_ZERO_PATTERN,         /* Empty pattern (zero length) */
00115     ACERR_AUTOMATA_CLOSED,      /* Automata is closed. after calling
00116                                  * ac_automata_finalize() you can not add new 
00117                                  * patterns to the automata. */
00118 } AC_STATUS_t;
00119 
00120 /* AC_MATCH_CALBACK_t:
00121  * This is the call-back function to report match back to the caller.
00122  * when a match is find, the automata will reach you using this function and sends
00123  * you a pointer to AC_MATCH_t. using that pointer you can handle
00124  * matches. you can send parameters to the call-back function when you call
00125  * ac_automata_search(). at call-back, the automata will sent you those
00126  * parameters as the second parameter (void *) of AC_MATCH_CALBACK_t. inside
00127  * the call-back function you can cast it to whatever you want.
00128  * If you return 0 from AC_MATCH_CALBACK_t function to the automata, it will
00129  * continue searching, otherwise it will return from ac_automata_search()
00130  * to your calling function.
00131 **/
00132 typedef int (*AC_MATCH_CALBACK_f)(AC_MATCH_t *, void *);
00133 
00134 /* AC_PATTRN_MAX_LENGTH:
00135  * Maximum acceptable pattern length in AC_PATTERN_t.length
00136 **/
00137 #define AC_PATTRN_MAX_LENGTH 1024
00138 
00139 #ifdef __cplusplus
00140 }
00141 #endif
00142 
00143 #endif
